nodes.text:
The SPINDLE Chamber Floor smells like cold dust and warmed insulation.
The containment sphere sits in its cradle, matte and over-insulated—
then, for a fraction of a second, it isn’t.
The surface flickers reflective, like a mirror that would prefer a different room.
The floor signage still reads NORMAL OPERATIONS, which is either optimism or fraud.

choices.text: use: Acknowledge HOLD condition and begin documentation packet.

nodes.text:
Up close, the sphere is mostly matte—industrial, honest, designed to be ignored.
Then it catches the room wrong. The reflection isn’t you from any angle you can stand in.
It flickers back to matte before your eyes finish reporting it.
Hold it. (pause) Watch your words. (pause) Don’t put “mirror” or “responsive” in the log. (pause) Use “reflective behavior.” (pause) That’s legacy-report language. (pause) Already filed.

choices.text: ask: “Is it safe to stand here?”

nodes.text:
‘Held’? That’s compliance talk. (pause)
We say stable/armed/inhibit/operator error. (pause)
‘Held’ reads like someone’s actively holding it. (pause)
And no, that’s not me.

Don't say "safe" (pause) it summons a crowd. (pause) My panel shows no proximity interlock violation. (pause) If it goes fully reflective and stays (pause) step back (pause) and log "visual condition change." (pause) Keep it boring. (pause) Boring survives testimony.
Good. Add time and location. (pause) Say you stayed outside the barrier stripe. (pause) That sentence keeps you employed.

The status indicator cluster is lit with careful colors: greens that mean “allowed,” ambers that mean “pending,” reds that mean “someone else’s problem.”
One amber lamp is labeled in a different font: HOLD / NON-LOCAL.
The label looks like it arrived already archived.
That’s new.
Careful with “new.” (pause) It implies we changed something. (pause) Say “newly visible.” (pause) It says we noticed.
No who field. Just authority. (pause) Get the notice number first, before heroics.
Alarms, sure. Clear those here. (pause) A hold won’t clear local. (pause) That’s remote-office insurance.

The printed tag list is half facility jargon, half something that pretends to be facility jargon.
STANDING INDICATOR: UNKNOWN.
SERVICE CLASS: UNRESOLVED.
The rest is ordinary, which is how it hides.

The interface scan panel is a waist-high slab of glass with a keypad that assumes obedience.
Its prompt is cheerful in the way compliance software is cheerful:
ENTER TARGET / SELECT FORM / SUBMIT.
Treat it like a copier. Scan. Submit. Done. (pause) Start talking to it. (pause) Suddenly, you’ve got stakeholders.

choices.text: use: Scan sphere surface as target.
use: Pull last system notice / routing message.
persuade: Submit formal presence note (OLEA signatory language).

nodes.text:
The panel chirps once, pleased with itself.
A line prints across the screen as if it’s always been there:
NOTICE: UNAUTHORIZED LOAD DETECTED.
ORIGIN NODE: SOL-EARTH-LOCAL.
MANAGING AUTHORITY: METASTABLE TRANSFER AUTHORITY (MTA).
ACTION: HOLD STATE PENDING COMPLIANCE.
REFERENCE: [a number that looks too clean to be local].

choices.text: ask: Identify the reference format (for the log).
use: Print / save notice to log tray.

nodes.text:
You expand the reference field.
The digits reflow to fit, like the system was waiting for permission to be specific.
Read the number back. (pause) Out loud. (pause) Then print it. (pause) Everyone needs to hear you didn't invent it.

The reference string is structured like an external docket: prefix, jurisdiction stub, and a queue-like suffix.
It’s designed to be cited, not understood.

You can’t place the format with confidence.
It’s too clean, too standardized—like it expects your systems to already agree with it.
Standing depends on who’s judging. (pause) Local your badge works. (pause) Non local: eligible to be processed. (pause) Yeah. (pause) Use their phrase. Don’t polish it.

The nearby printer wakes like it’s been pretending not to exist.
A dot-matrix page tears out, barcodes crisp enough to feel insulting.
The header reads like a contractor letter until you get to MTA.
Good. Keep the original. (pause) Don’t paraphrase it from memory. (pause) Attach the page. (pause) Let the machine own it.

The panel scrolls a short list of messages.
Most are dull: filter changes, lubrication intervals, overdue inspections.
One entry is not dull. It is precise.
HOLD — NON-LOCAL COMPLIANCE — PENDING DOCUMENTATION — MTA REF [the same too-clean number].
Okay.
Yeah. Now make it attributable: print it. (pause) Annotate it. (pause) Stick it in the closure packet.
Submitting presence note. OLEA signatory. On-site, in control.
Good. Keep it boring. (pause) On-site is a physical claim. (pause) Defensible. No motives. No theories. (pause) Just that you're here.

The panel accepts the note without celebrating.
A confirmation code appears, then immediately asks if you want a hard copy.

The printer produces a thin receipt that looks like nothing.
The kind of nothing that wins arguments.
Staple it to the front. (pause) It proves you were present. (pause) When it didn’t work.

The emergency stop is a red mushroom button under a clear flip cover.
The cover is scuffed from hands that stopped just short of being responsible.

You can hit it yeah. (pause) Once you do (pause) you've made a declaration. (pause) Committees love declarations. (pause) If you touch it (pause) I need a reason phrase (pause) and a timestamp—nothing emotional.

It drops local motion control. (pause) Trips the local breakers. (pause)
The non-local hold stays. (pause) The paperwork stays. (pause)
And your planned sequence argument goes away.

The placard reads: EMERGENCY STOP — USE ONLY TO PREVENT IMMINENT HARM.
Below that, in smaller print: ACTIVATION REQUIRES POST-EVENT REPORT.
Someone underlined REPORT twice.

You don’t fix the hold. You make it legible.
You print the notice. You capture the reference number. You create a timestamped chain that says you were here, and you saw it, and you did not improvise alone.
The sphere flickers once more—mirror, matte—like it’s being kept open on purpose.
The room accepts your paperwork the way it accepts power: without gratitude.

You step toward the stairs down to the Observation Deck.
Behind you, the sphere keeps its own time, interrupting your vision like a clerical correction.

You angle toward the Overflow Intake Concourse.
The chamber stays behind glass and signage, still insisting—quietly—that someone should be on record.
